Variation Example: An old couple spread pitch on a straw calf. One after another, a bear, a wolf, a fox, & a rabbit touch the calf & stick to it. In return for not being slaughtered, they promise to bring cows, horses, geese & cabbage. Thus the animals ransom themselves & the old people get rich.
Sitting in a tree, a man hears a lion, a dog, a cat & an eagle quarreling over a dead stag (donkey). They ask the man to arbitrate.

Classifications: Animals Warm Selves at Charcoal Burner's Fire
Variation Example: They are sent after food for dinner. Each of them brings some back, but the charcoal burner drives them away or kills them.

A lion (bear) helps a man with his work. The man praises his virtues but criticises the bad smell of his mouth. The lion forces the man to strike him on his head with an axe. After a year, the man & the lion meet again. The lion says that his wound is healed but it stills hurts, & devours the man. In some variants the man’s wife complains about the lion. The lion overhears this & forces the man to wound him.
In order to demonstrate the superiority of humans over animals, a man shows a lion a statue of a conquered lion. The lion replies that if a lion had made the statue, it would have looked different.

A traveler saves a tiger (lion, crow), a monkey (bear), a snake, & a man (jeweler) from a pit (from a tree trunk floating in a flood). The animals give their rescuer a reward or promise to help him later. One animal gives him stolen jewels. The man also promises to reward the rescuer but later he denies it. He accuses the rescuer before the king of having stolen the jewels. The rescuer is to be punished. The snake saves him by biting the king’s child & then showing the rescuer the proper remedy. The traveler is freed & the jeweler is punished. Often the traveler is warned not to rescue the man.
A woman is attacked by a bear in the forest. The bear lays her down near a stump of a tree & starts to dig a hole. The woman ties her head-covering to the stump & slips away.

A farmer hides a fox from the hunters in a basket, & promises not to betray him. When the hunters come, he says, “The fox just went over the hill”, but he points to the basket. The hunters do not see this. When the farmer asks the fox to thank him, the fox answers that he would have thanked him if gestures & words had agreed with each other.

A poor old man cuts off a sleeping bear’s leg with an axe. His wife cooks the leg & spins the fur into yarn. The bear makes himself a leg from linden wood. At night he comes to the house & eats the old man. Or, the bear comes to the house & sings about what was done to him, “All the people are asleep; so are the little birds. Only one old woman is awake, & she spins my wool & boils my flesh.”

Classifications: Master Looks More Closely Than the Farmhand
Variation Example: A stag hides from hunters in a stable, but the cows warn him that he would be more secure in the forest. The farmhand does not notice him, but the master finds him & kills him.

Classifications: The Wolf Steals & Eats One Sheep
Variation Example: The Wolf Steals & Eats One Sheep, then two, & finally the whole herd & the shepherd. The wolf is killed.
By his singing (threats or compliments) the wolf compels an old man to surrender his cattle, his children & grandchildren, & finally his wife. In the end the wolf eats the man.

The wolf promises to give up eating flesh. When he finds a pig in a puddle, he says, “It’s fish, not flesh”, & eats it up. Or, the wolf promises to give up killing animals & wants to be a saint. On his way to the desert he wrings the neck of a gander. He excuses himself, saying: “He should not have hissed at a saint”.

Classifications: The Wolf is Punished by being Married
Variation Example: The wolf is condemned to the most severe punishment. He is forced to get married. In some variants the wolf must take two wives.

Classifications: The Wolf Puts his Tail through the Window
Variation Example: The Wolf Puts His Tail through the Window of the stable & alarms the sheep. The farmer snatches at the tail & tears it off.

Classifications: The Wolf tries to Get Horses
Variation Example: In the night a wolf comes near the horses. He plunges into the river & then shakes near the fire to exstinguish it or he wallows in the mud to splash it into the eyes of the horses. A sleeping driver awakes, seizes the wolf’s tail & tears it off.

Classifications: The Musician in the Wolf Trap
Variation Example: A violinist falls into a wolf’s hole (sometimes together with a bear). There he encounters a wolf already trapped, & saves himself by playing music until someone (sometimes the bear) helps him out of the hole. The wolf is killed.

Classifications: The Old Woman & the Wolf Fall into the Pit Together
Variation Example: The old woman urges the wolf & other animals to sit still. She is rescued by a hunter who either kills the animals or saves them.

Three main themes can be distinguished: (1) Tales of wolves that do not attack the people they meet. (2) Tales of wolves that harm or want to harm people. (3) Tales of wolves that are punished by people.

Classifications: The Man Drives with a Tub & Little Pigs
Variation Example: Wolves attack a man. He pulls a tub over himself & the little pigs. The wolves put their paws under the tub & the man splits them with a knife.

A fox who has a shoe spends the night in a house with a rooster. The fox destroys the shoe & blames the rooster, which he demands as reparation. The next night, in another house, the fox eats the rooster, & in the morning he accuses a sheep of having eaten it. He demands the sheep. In the next house he blames the ox for having eaten the sheep, etc.

Classifications: The Bear Plays with the Boar's Young
Variation Example: A boar pursues him. The bear climbs up a tree, but the branch breaks & the bear falls down on the boar. They fight each other & the bear is killed.

Classifications: Human & Animal Life Spans are Readjusted
Variation Example: God (Zeus) originally gives 30 years to all animals & humans. Donkey, dog & monkey refuse some of their years because of their sufferings. Man wants to have more years & takes them from the animals. Therefore in the middle of their lives people must do the hard work of a donkey, then they bark like old dogs, & at last they are foolish like monkeys.

A cunning rabbit (hare, fox, jackal) steals fruit from a garden (field). A figure spread with tar, wax or glue is set out to trap the thief. The rabbit tries to make the tarbaby talk & finally becomes so angry that he strikes it. He sticks to the tarbaby & is captured. The rabbit is punished.

A tiger overhears a person saying that he fears something worse than the tiger. The word is unknown to the tiger (dripping of rain, sweet, twilight). Thinking it must be a terrible thing, the tiger hides (sometimes among sheep) & is found by a drunken man (thief) who mistakes him for his horse. He rides off on the tiger (steals it because it seems to be a very big sheep). The tiger thinks the man must be the terrible thing he has heard about & meekly submits. In the morning the man sees his mistake & flees.
The Faithful Animal Rashly Killed

A dog (cat, mouse) saves his master’s child from a snake. When the master sees the dog’s bloody mouth, he thinks the dog has eaten the child & kills it. Later on he finds the dead snake & realizes his mistake.

Classifications: The Faithful Dog as Security for a Debt
Variation Example: A poor man leaves his dog with a wealthy man as security for a large loan. The dog helps the wealthy man by retrieving stolen goods & driving off thieves. The grateful man sends the dog back to its owner with a letter saying the debt is cancelled. The owner, thinking the dog has run away, kills it before he finds the letter.

Classifications: The Thirsty King Kills HIs Faithful Falcon
Variation Example: A king who is out hunting is about to drink a cup of water. His falcon (horse) knocks the cup from his hand. The enraged king kills the falcon. Then he finds out that the cup was full of poison from a snake.

Classifications: What the bear whispered in his ear
Variation Example: A traveler & his guide (two friends) go through a forest in which they meet a dangerous bear. The guide climbs a tree & leaves the traveler at the mercy of the bear. The traveler feigns death & the bear sniffs at him & leaves.
This misc. type consists of various tales in which the bear is generally hurt (killed).
A bear pursues a man who hides in a bush. When the bear puts his paws around the bush, the man rips open the bear’s belly.

Classifications: Man & Bear Hold Each Other Around a Tree
Variation Example: A man & a bear take hold of each other around a tree & will not let go. Another man hurries home for help, but does not come back for a long time. When he comes at last, his comrade, who is holding the bear’s paws, makes him to take his place & goes away. He also stays away for a long time, to take revenge for his friend’s thoughtlessness.

Classifications: An Old Man Carrying a Kneading Trough
Variation Example: A man goes through the forest, lies down to rest, & draws a trough over himself. A hare, a wolf, a fox, & a bear come & admire the fine little table. All of them bring something to eat: a cabbage, a lamb, a goose, some honey. Then the man under the table moves, the animals run away & the man gets all their food.
A hunter who has killed several animals is bitten by a snake. A jackal comes by & nibbles at the hunter’s bowstring. He is killed when the bow rebounds.

Classifications: The Man Tells the Leopard's Secret
Variation Example: A lizard & leopard (tiger) play hide & seek. The lizard fastens himself (a crab) onto the leopard’s tail or coats himself with mud so that the leopard cannot grab him. A man witnesses their contest. The leopard is ashamed & threatens him unless he maintains silence. The man betrays the secret & the leopard carries him off. The man escapes by making a noise so that the leopard thinks that the lizard is coming, or by saying he has eggs from which lizards will soon hatch.
The helpful animal sees a snake bite his master. He catches a crow, who is the snake’s confederate, & forces the snake to revive his master by sucking out the poison.
The rabbit says he will dance when the gate is opened. He escapes.

Classifications: Half of the Money thrown into the Water
Variation Example: A man makes money by selling milk (wine) mixed with water. A monkey throws the man’s money alternately into water & on land (ship) because the man sold half water & half milk.

A man who sells nightcaps puts one on & lies down to sleep. Some monkeys steal some of his caps & put them on. When the man wakes up & sees that the monkeys have his nightcaps, he takes his off & throws it in anger down on the ground. The monkeys copy him, so he gets his night-caps back.
